@gglanzani can you please update the tests to cover this?

nit: please correct the commit title per template (see other PRs)
Hi @NielsZeilemaker thanks for your contribution. Your tests seem a bit weirdly placed, why not just unit tests the affected functions?
Good catch. Unit tests are required though. The environment for this should really be simple. No db is required to do so or any other integrations.
@bolkedebruin I partly agree that my tests are more end-to-end than unit. I've added a test in models which verifies if a filter ends up in the jinja environment
cc @criccomini maybe for 1.8.1?

@NielsZeilemaker Thanks. Can you please move your dummy_operator tests into tests/models.py? And then squash your commits? Rest LGTM

> **Legend** - [Click here to learn more](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/codecov-delta)
> `Δ = absolute <relative> (impact)`, `ø = not affected`, `? = missing data`
> Powered by [Codecov](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2260?src=pr&el=footer). Last update [c2472ff...49cc71a](https://codecov.io/gh/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2260?src=pr&el=lastupdated). Read the [comment docs](https://docs.codecov.io/docs/pull-request-comments).
@aoen @saguziel @amaliujia I consider this a better fix than https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2236 as it is not just subdags affected.
Please see https://github.com/apache/incubator-airflow/pull/2260 for a more comprehensive fix.

@bolkedebruin You mean write the tests for the entire hook, don't you?

I've added a first draft for the tests.
Is using the prefix the canonical way of identifying backfills?
I have modified my commit messages according to your mentioned guideline. Is that ok to merge?

I just queried our Airflow DB, and found a bunch of dagruns with "scheduled_" run_id prefix but belong to subdag DAGs.

I agree this PR's idea is better(cover backfill jobs). But it might be better to do filtering by querying DB. I updated #2236 and so now it queries DB and filtering out dagruns of subdag. 

I would suggest that still query DB to do filtering.

@amaliujia if you are running already with your patch you would see those in your db. It should not happen without it ("scheduled" in db for sub dag) <== I might be wrong here

*** please show me how a sub dag gets a scheduled run_id ***

If you still think that can happen please provide evidence how that can happen, ie where a subdag can get to "scheduled" dag run id. 

Also note the issue can also happen with normal backfills not just sub dags.
(Sorry was typing on a phone)

LGTM. I've tested this PR and am comfortable that it reliably addresses the issue we were seeing. (We are heavy users of subdags and had a test DAG with subdags that we used to recreate the issue consistently. I've been running that test DAG against this PR every few minutes without issue.)

@amaliujia I just looked in our Airflow DB and I can't find any rows in dag_run where a subdag had a run_id starting with 'scheduled_'. (I used 'WHERE dag_id LIKE '%.%' to filter for subdags. We have quite a lot of them so I'm pretty confident I would have seen one if it was possible.)
@saguziel it is yes (unfortunately)

Hi @bolkedebruin,
The following line causes the "mark success" not to work.
`execution_date = execution_date.replace(microsecond=0)`
I tried using postgresql/mysql 5.5/5.6/5.7.
They are all saving datetime with millisecond.
But when you query the DB:
`drs = DagRun.find(dag_id=dag.dag_id, execution_date=dates)`
It's not there since you truncated the microseconds.
Any reason?
Waiting to merge until @amaliujia responds.
I rechecked the DB and the case I mentioned were old entries. Sorry about that so LGTM.
@amaliujia - I agree with you that we should do filtering on the DB side.
What's the advantage of going with a blacklist (i.e. not scheduling backfill DAGs) vs. a whitelist (i.e. scheduling only DAG runs created by the scheduler)? Is it to handle user-created DAG runs?

@plypaul yes (see also scheduler logic). 

I'm ok with changing to filtering in the db, however the impact should be small (run_id is not indexed in this case)
I'm assuming ok to merge after tests pass (lookup happens in DB now).
@saguziel, thanks for your PR! By analyzing the history of the files in this pull request, we identified @mistercrunch, @bolkedebruin and @jlowin to be potential reviewers.
SHA1 intentionally, doesn't need to be super secure, don't want it to be slow on machines that don't have hardware support for SHA2
This changes existing functionality (potentially breaking some use cases), it should be a new option (randomized_delay), and the config options should be parameterized (e.g. min delay, max delay...)
@MrMaksimize, thanks for your PR! By analyzing the history of the files in this pull request, we identified @artwr, @jlowin and @msumit to be potential reviewers.

@bolkedebruin I've moved the tests and did a squashed all my commits
@wangxisea, thanks for your PR! By analyzing the history of the files in this pull request, we identified @mistercrunch, @bolkedebruin and @artwr to be potential reviewers.
Something is out of whack here.  Closing this for now, will reopen after resolution.
There's already max_retry_delay. I don't think this is really used considering the implementation was broken before. I can't really see what use case this would break.
Ok I agree, but I still think randomized delay should be user configurable (base delay, delay multiplier, exponent)

Base delay is taken from the retry_delay field which is configurable. Not sure what multiplier is, but I don't think configuring the exponent is really something ever wanted, and just blows up the code with more unnecessary configuration options.
I'm not sure that it's unnecessary, these configuration values are very use-case specific, guess we can add them later though, LGTM.
Thanks. Tests are not running unfortunately. To resolve this please rename your test file to "test_hive.py" and then squash your commits.
The [tests are passing](https://travis-ci.org/patrickmckenna/incubator-airflow/builds/227178887).
@cameres, thanks for your PR! By analyzing the history of the files in this pull request, we identified @Fokko, @danielvdende and @hgrif to be potential reviewers.
